verses.text: When the wedding feast ended, Tobit called his son Tobias and said, "My son, see to it that you pay the wages of the man who went with you, and give him a bonus as well."
verses.comment: Tobit's insistence on just wages connects to biblical themes of fairness (Lev 19:13; Deut 24:14-15; Jas 5:4).

verses.text: He replied, "Father, how much should I give him? It would not hurt to give him half of all that he brought back with me."
verses.comment: Tobias demonstrates a spirit of gratitude fit for generous compensation.

verses.text: "He has led me back to you safe and sound, healed my wife, brought me the money, and even healed you. How much more can I reward him?"
verses.comment: The works described correspond to both spiritual and corporal acts of mercy—a foreshadowing of Christ's ministry (cf. Lk 4:18-19).

verses.text: Tobit said, "He surely deserves half of all he brought back."
verses.comment: Half the possessions: emphasizes the inestimable value of divine assistance, beyond earthly wealth.

verses.text: So Tobias called Raphael and said, "Take as your wages half of all that you brought back, and go in peace."
verses.comment: Giving generously mirrors biblical ethics about hospitality and thanksgiving for God's messengers (Heb 13:2).

verses.text: Then Raphael called them both aside and said, "Praise God and thank him. Celebrate him before all the living for the good things he has done for you and to bless his name. Declare to all people the wonderful things God has done. Do not be slow to give him thanks."
verses.comment: Raphael's instruction reflects the central biblical call to praise God publicly (Ps 66:16).

verses.text: "It is good to keep the secret of a king, but it is fine to reveal and praise what is the work of God. Do good, and evil will not overtake you."
verses.comment: Contrast between human secrecy and the glorification of God's works, paralleling Jesus' command to proclaim God's deeds (Mt 10:27).

verses.text: "Prayer is good with fasting, and almsgiving with righteousness. A little with righteousness is better than much with injustice. It is better to give alms than to store up gold."
verses.comment: Affirms that prayer, fasting, and almsgiving are spiritually beneficial—a triad commended throughout both Testaments (see Mt 6; Joel 2:12-13). Early Christians continued these practices as a means of grace.

verses.text: "Almsgiving saves from death and purges every sin. Those who give alms will enjoy long life."
verses.comment: The teaching that almsgiving atones for sin (cf. Prov 16:6) influenced early Christian theology and the tradition of charitable works as an expression of living faith (see Jas 2:14-17).

verses.text: "But those who commit sin and do evil are enemies to their own lives."
verses.comment: Sin is not just an offense against God but self-destructive (cf. Rom 6:23), a theme running through both Law and Gospel.

verses.text: "I will now tell you the whole truth and conceal nothing from you. I have already said that it is good to reveal and praise what is the work of God."
verses.comment: He prepares to disclose his true identity, echoing the biblical importance of testimony to God's action.

verses.text: "When you and your daughter-in-law Sarah prayed, I brought your prayers before the Holy One. When you buried the dead, I was there also."
verses.comment: The mediation of angels carrying prayers is repeated in Revelation (5:8; 8:3-4), strengthening the biblical motif of intercession and the communion of saints.

verses.text: "When you did not hesitate to get up and leave your meal to go and bury the dead, your action was remembered before God."
verses.comment: Burying the dead is highlighted in later Christian tradition as a corporal work of mercy, emphasizing the sanctity of charity.

verses.text: "So now, when you and Sarah prayed, I presented your petition before the Lord. As for you, you would not hesitate to get up and leave your meal to care for the dead, so God sent me to heal you and your daughter-in-law Sarah."
verses.comment: Tobit's compassion and prayers are presented to God by the angel, demonstrating the biblical affirmation of mediation in prayer.

verses.text: "I am Raphael, one of the seven angels who stand and serve before the glory of the Lord."
verses.comment: The seven angels are later referenced in Revelation (8:2), and Gabriel's similar self-introduction in Lk 1:19 further links the Old and New Testament presence of God's messengers.

verses.text: The two of them trembled; they fell facedown in fear.
verses.comment: The awe in the presence of an angel recalls similar responses to theophanies throughout Scripture (e.g., Dan 10:9, Acts 9:4).

verses.text: But the angel said to them, "Do not be afraid; peace be with you. Bless God forever.
verses.comment: "Do not be afraid"—God’s messengers consistently bring peace, echoing greetings at the Annunciation and Resurrection appearances (Lk 1:30; Jn 20:19).

verses.text: "As for me, I was not acting on my own, but by the will of God. Bless him each day and sing his praises."
verses.comment: Raphael's humility before God underscores the pattern of obedience and harmonious work among God’s servants in heaven and earth.

verses.text: "You saw me eat and drink, but that was only a vision. I did not really eat or drink; it only appeared so to you."
verses.comment: The ability of spiritual beings to appear physically—highlighting the mysterious ways of angels (cf. Gen 18:8), as also reflected when Christ, in his resurrected body, eats with the apostles (Lk 24:41-43).

verses.text: "So now, thank the Lord on earth and bless God. Behold, I am ascending to the One who sent me. Write down all these things that have happened to you."
verses.comment: Raphael's 'ascension' prefigures Christ's return to the Father (Acts 1:9). The command to write/record recalls biblical mandates for testifying to God's works (Exod 34:27; Ps 102:18).

verses.text: Then they stood up, and could no longer see him.
verses.comment: The sudden departure echoes other moments when the divine is veiled after revelation (Lk 24:31; Acts 1:9).

verses.text: They praised God and gave thanks for his marvelous deeds, for he had revealed his mercy and greatness to them.
verses.comment: End concludes with praise, highlighting giving thanks for God's mercy—a theme central to biblical faith and genuine spiritual life.
